page.title: 17NATURE RESERVE ON ARNE
page.content: The path emerges into a sandy beach, and a developing sand spit can be seen. This is being colonised by small plants.The sand is a dry and unstable soil and the plants have long roots to reach moisture.Trampling by visitors has destroyed the vegetation and the neck of the spit,but further along,sea couch grass and sea lyme grass have stabilised the ridge crest. The cliffs at the back of the beach are composed of Bagshot sands and acidic gravels,which are easily leached,and therefore poor for agriculture.The cliffs are being slowly eroded by wind and rain,and mass movement ie, slumps and slides,is common.Offshore black-headed and herring gulls,cormorants and oyster catchers can be seen on the wing,and also settling on the shores of Long and Round Islands.
